(°C) 1 0.28 5 135 40.1 2 0.84 5 135 62.2 3 0.28 15 135 77.5 4 0.84 15 135 97.7 5 0.28 10 120 39.2 6 0.84 10 120 94.7 7 0.28 10 150 95.9 8 0.84 10 150 98.4 9 0.56 5 120 48.0 10 0.56 15 120 51.0 11 0.56 5 150 52.0 12 0.56 15 150 99.5 13 0.56 10 135 92.0 14 0.56 10 135 92.4 15 0.56 10 135 91.9 Research Paper Multifunctional alkanolamine as a catalyst for CO2 and propylene oxide cycloaddition Hyeon-Gook Kim a b Chung-Sun Lim b Dong-Woo Kim b Deug-Hee Cho b Dong-Koo Lee b Jin Suk Chung a ⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering and Bioengineering, University of Ulsan, 93 Daehakro, Nam-gu, Ulsan 44610, Republic of Korea School of Chemical Engineering and Bioengineering University of Ulsan 93 Daehakro Nam-gu Ulsan 44610 Republic of Korea b Chemical Industry Development Center, Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology, 45 Jongga-ro, Jung-gu, Ulsan 44412, Republic of Korea Chemical Industry Development Center Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology 45 Jongga-ro Jung-gu Ulsan 44412 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Multifunctional alkanolamines without metals or halides were designed as catalysts for the synthesis of propylene carbonate (PC) by the cycloaddition of CO2 and propylene oxide (PO). New catalysts were synthesized in a one-step, low-temperature reaction. Among the multifunctional alkanolamine catalysts, bis(methylpiperazinyl)triol (Catalyst 1) showed the best performance, with a 96% yield of PO in 3h at 120°C and 10bar using 1mol% catalyst. A 90% yield of PO could be obtained using 5.60mol% of Catalyst 1 under mild conditions (100°C and 5bar). A reaction mechanism was proposed based on the synergistic effects between the hydroxyl and amine groups in one multifunctional molecule. The effects of the reaction parameters (temperature, CO2 pressure, and catalyst loading) on the yield of PC were interpreted using response surface methodology. The metal- and halide-free catalysts will facilitate an environmentally friendly process for the application of other carbonates. Keywords Alkanolamine Carbon dioxide fixation Cycloaddition Organocatalysis Propylene carbonate 1 Introduction Substantial CO2 emissions from the massive consumption of fossil fuels have brought about global warming and climate change [1–3]. Extensive research has been undertaken toward reducing CO2 emissions to identify three possible strategies to diminish CO2 buildup in the atmosphere: (i) reducing the amount of CO2 produced, (ii) utilizing the emitted CO2, or (iii) storing the emitted CO2 [4,5]. Among the alternatives, using CO2 as a feedstock in chemical production is an interesting route for commercial production of valuable materials. CO2 can be converted to useful chemicals, such as urea, salicylic acid, inorganic carbonates, pigments, cyclic organic carbonates, and additives for the synthesis of methanol [6]. Of all the possible conversions of CO2 to C1 or higher-carbon chemicals using molecular catalysts, the most promising reactions in terms of market needs, catalyst performance, and reusability are the formation of cyclic carbonates (e.g., propylene carbonate (PC)) by reacting CO2 with epoxides (e.g., propylene oxide (PO)); Scheme 1 [7–14]. Moreover, the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides is atom-efficient, and it is one of the most successful examples of CO2 fixation, producing cyclic carbonates that can be used as excellent aprotic polar solvents, intermediates in the pharmaceutical and fine chemical industries, and precursors for polycarbonate materials [15–17]. Numerous catalyst systems have been successfully deployed to materialize CO2-epoxide coupling [18,19], including ionic liquids, metal oxides [20,21], modified molecular sieves [22,23], supported catalysts [24–28], metal–organic frameworks with lodged metallic centers and/or halide anions [29–32], and metal-free catalysts [33–35]. An environmentally friendly organic catalyst that does not contain metals or halogens could be favorable for developing inexpensive and green processes. In essence, organocatalysts act as nucleophiles in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates by opening the epoxide ring prior to the addition of CO2 and subsequent cyclization [36,37]. Several types of metal-free catalysts for this reaction have been presented, including halides containing weakly interacting cations (e.g., ammonium and imidazolium) [38–40], nitrogen donor bases [41–43], and bifunctional organocatalysts that show synergistic effects of nucleophilic halide salts and a hydroxyl-containing electrophile [44–49]. Bifunctional organocatalysts for the production of cyclic carbonates have undergone remarkable developments in the past decade because of the ingenious design of catalysts, resulting in excellent yields and selectivities because of the synergy effect [44–48]. Hydrogen bonding–inspired organocatalysts and carboxyl-containing organocatalysts, including EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) and polyphenol for CO2 fixation with epoxides to form cyclic carbonates, demonstrate the utility of hydrogen bonding in this reaction [50,51]. The immobilization of phosphonium halides on silica dramatically increased the catalytic activities compared to the corresponding homogeneous onium salts by the promotion of synergistic effects by silica [25]. Another example is polarization of the oxygen atom by hydrogen bonding of OH groups and nucleophilic activation of the carbon atom by the anion, which was proposed for synergetic promotion of the cycloaddition reactions of CO2 and epoxides [52]. Using a halogen-containing organic catalyst, the reaction was performed under moderate conditions to obtain a reaction activity close to 100% [53–55]. Therefore, the catalyst must be designed properly so that synergistic effects can occur. Alkanolamines, commonly used as CO2 scrubbers, were first applied to catalyze the insertion of CO2 into epoxides, generating cyclic carbonates [48]. These experiments are limited to commercially available CO2 absorbents and are not likely to be a substitute for halide-containing organocatalysts because they provide a low yield. No previous attempts have been made to design and synthesize metal- and halide-free organocatalysts for CO2 conversion. In this report, we designed and prepared a series of metal- and halide-free multifunctional alkanolamines for the production of PC to achieve a more environmentally friendly and higher performance catalyst for CO2 conversion. Furthermore, the synergetic effects of amines and hydroxyl groups were studied. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Materials CO2 (99.999% purity) was used without further purification. Propylene oxide (Aldrich, 99%), 1-methylpiperazine (Aldrich, 99%), glycerol diglycidyl ether (Aldrich, technical grade), ethylene glycol diglycidyl ether (TCI), glycidol (Aldrich, 96%), trimethylolpropane triglycidyl ether (Aldrich, technical grade), 1-(2-hydroxyethyl)piperazine (Aldrich, 98%), 1,3-diaminopropane (Aldrich, 99%), 1-(2-aminoethyl)piperazine (Aldrich, 99%), and methanol (MeOH, HPLC grade) were purchased and used without further purification. N,N-diethyl glycidyl amine (99%) was synthesized according to a previous method [56]. 2.2 Instruments Gas chromatography (Bruker 450-GC) with a flame ionization detector and capillary column (HP-5, 5% phenyl methylpolysiloxane) was used to analyze PO and PC with an internal standard of biphenyl. 1H NMR spectra were obtained using a 300MHz Bruker Avance DPX-400 spectrometer with CDCl3 as the solvent to analyze the structures of the organic catalysts. Elemental analysis was performed using a Thermo Scientific Flash 2000. 2.3 Simulation experiment All of the DFT (density functional theory) quantum mechanical calculations were performed by applying the Becke three-parameter B3LYP hybrid exchange-correlation functional using the Gaussian 03 software package. The standard 6–31G(d) basis set was used for the geometry optimizations and frequency calculations [57]. In the Box-Behnken design (BBD), all of the data were analyzed with the assistance of the Expert Design 9 software package, and the significant second-order coefficients were selected by regression analysis with backward elimination from the analysis of variance (ANOVA) [57]. 2.4 Cycloaddition reaction For each typical batch operation, PO and the catalysts were charged in the reactor without a solvent and purged several times with CO2. The reactor was then pressurized with CO2 to 10bar at room temperature. The reaction was initiated at the target temperature while stirring at 500rpm for the reaction time. The reaction was performed in a stainless steel autoclave reactor (50mL) equipped with a magnetic stirrer. PO (5.0g) and the selected catalyst were charged in the reactor, and CO2 gas was flowed through the reactor a few times. The CO2 pressure was increased in the reactor to the preset value at room temperature with stirring (500rpm). At the reaction temperature (100–150°C), the solubilities of PO and the catalyst are good and do not affect the results. Once the reaction was complete, the reactor was allowed to cool to room temperature and CO2 was vented. 2.5 Preparation of the catalysts Epoxy chemicals are often used as epoxy resins; they were designed to produce a tertiary amine and hydroxyl group by reacting with secondary amines (Catalyst 1–Catalyst 5 (1–5)). Epoxy reactants containing two or three epoxies (ethylene glycol diglycidyl ether, trimethylolpropane triglycidyl ether (11)) and epoxy chemicals containing a hydroxyl group (glycerol diglycidyl ether (8), glycidol (10)) were also used as reactants. An epoxy reactant containing a hydroxyl group can undergo self-coupling; therefore, it should be stored at low temperatures, and a sufficiently low temperature (10°C) should be maintained during the experiments to prevent self-coupling. The cyclic structure of the piperazine group (1-methylpiperazine (9), 1-(2-hydroxyethyl) piperazine) was used as a secondary amine. The reaction of piperazine with epoxy and the reaction conditions are similar to the dendrimer polymer synthesis process [58]. The synthetic routes for Catalyst 1, Catalyst 3, and Catalyst 4 are shown in Scheme 2 (a)–(c), respectively. Further, epichlorohydrin, which contains an epoxy group, was reacted with diethylamine to produce the N,N-diethyl glycidyl amine (12) and then reacted with a primary amine (1,3-diaminopropane) to produce a multifunctional organic catalyst (Catalyst 6 (6) and Catalyst 7 (7)) containing the ethyl amine groups. The synthetic route for Catalyst 7 is shown in Scheme 2(d). 2.5.1 Catalyst 1 (bis(methylpiperazinyl)triol) 1-Methylpiperazine (30g) and MeOH (50mL) were added to a 250-mL round-bottomed flask with mechanical stirring. Glycerol diglycidyl ether (20.4g) in MeOH (20mL) was added to this mixture dropwise over a period of 5min. The mixture was stirred at 20°C for 20h under nitrogen. NMR analysis demonstrated the absence of epoxide. Volatiles were removed by rotary evaporation, and the excess 1-methylpiperazine was removed using a high vacuum at 100°C for 1day to yield Catalyst 1 (44.3g; yield: 88%; yellow viscous liquid; 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3, 25°C, TMS) δ =2.24 (s, 6H), δ =2.3–2.7 (bm, 20H), δ =3.3–3.9 (bm, 22H); 13C NMR (75MHz, CDCl3): δ 45.9, 53.0, 55.0, 60.4, 66.1, 67.1, 71.3, 74.1; MS (ESI) m/e: calcd for C19H40N4O5 (M+): 404.30, found (M+H)+: 405.30; elemental analysis: calcd (%) for C19H40N4O5: C 56.41, H 9.97, N 13.85, O 19.77; found: C 56.86, H 9.95, N 13.89, O 19.30). 2.5.2 Catalyst 2 (bis(methylpiperazinyl)diol) 1-Methylpiperazine (30g) and MeOH (50mL) were added to a 250-mL round-bottomed flask with mechanical stirring. Ethylene glycol diglycidyl ether (20.225g) in MeOH (20mL) was added to this mixture dropwise over a period of 5min. The mixture was stirred at 20°C for 20h under nitrogen. NMR analysis demonstrated the absence of epoxide. Volatiles were removed by rotary evaporation, and the excess 1-methylpiperazine was removed using a high vacuum at 100°C for 1day to yield Catalyst 2 (45.7g; yield: 91%; yellow viscous liquid; 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3, 25°C, TMS) δ =1.58 (s, 4H), δ =2.2 (s, 6H), δ =2.22–2.7 (bm, 20H), δ =3.3–3.98 (bm, 10H); 13C NMR: 25.9, 45.7, 53.4, 54.8, 60.3, 65.7, 71.0, 73.0; MS (ESI) m/e: calcd for C20H42N4O4 (M+): 402.32, found (M+H)+: 403.3; elemental analysis: calcd (%) for C20H42N4O4: C 59.67, H 10.52, N 13.92, O 15.90; found: C 59.22, H 10.13, N 14.03, O 15.61). 2.5.3 Catalyst 3 (bis(methylpiperazinyl)diol) 1-Methylpiperazine (15g) and MeOH (50mL) were added to a 250-mL round-bottomed flask with mechanical stirring. Glycidol (7.0408g) in MeOH (20mL) was added to this mixture dropwise over a period of 5min. The mixture was stirred at 10°C for 20h under nitrogen. NMR analysis demonstrated the absence of epoxide. Volatiles were removed by rotary evaporation, and the excess 1-methylpiperazine was removed using a high vacuum at 100°C for 1day to yield Catalyst 3 (19.6g, 89%; yield: 89%; yellow liquid; 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3, 25°C, TMS) δ =2.25 (s, 3H), δ =2.25–2.75 (bm, 10H), δ =3.4–3.7 (bm, 2H), δ =3.8 (m, H); 13C NMR: 46.0, 55.0, 56.1, 60.8, 65.0, 66.9; MS (ESI) m/e: calcd for C8H18N2O2 (M+): 174.14, found (M+H)+: 175.1; elemental analysis: calcd (%) for C8H18N2O2: C 55.15, H 10.41, N 16.08, O 18.36; found: C 55.63, H 10.31, N 15.61, O 18.45). 2.5.4 Catalyst 4 (tris(methylpiperazine)triol) 1-Methylpiperazine (45g) and MeOH (50mL) were added to a 250-mL round-bottomed flask with mechanical stirring. Trimethylolpropane triglycidyl ether (30.237g) in MeOH (20mL) was added to this mixture dropwise over a period of 5min. This mixture was stirred at 20°C for 20h under nitrogen. NMR analysis demonstrated the absence of epoxide. Volatiles were removed by rotary evaporation, and the excess 1-methylpiperazine was removed using a high vacuum at 100°C for 1day to yield Catalyst 4 (66.2g, 88%; yield: 88%; yellow viscous liquid. 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3, 25°C, TMS) δ =0.79 (s, 3H), δ =1.33 (q, 2H), δ =2.24 (s, 6H), δ =2.3–2.7 (bm, 16H), δ =3.1–3.9 (bm, 21H); 13C NMR: 7.6, 23.0, 43.3, 45.9, 53.0, 55.0, 60.7, 66.2, 71.8, 74.0; MS (ESI) m/e: calcd for C30H62N6O6 (M+): 602.47, found (M+H)+: 603.5; elemental analysis: calcd (%) for C 59.77, H 10.37, N 13.94, O 15.92; found: C30H62N6O6: C 59.87, H 10.10, N 14.02, O 15.83). 2.5.5 Catalyst 5 (bis(hydroxyethylpiperazinyl)diol) 1-(2-Hydroxyethyl)piperazine (39.0g) and MeOH (50mL) were added to a 250-mL round-bottomed flask with mechanical stirring. Ethylene glycol diglycidyl ether (20.225g) in MeOH (20mL) was added to this mixture dropwise over a period of 5min. The mixture was heated at 80°C for 20h under nitrogen. NMR analysis demonstrated the absence of epoxide. Volatiles were removed by rotary evaporation, and excess 1-(2-hydroxyethyl)piperazine was removed using a high vacuum at 100°C for 1day to yield Catalyst 5 (52.7g, 89%; yield: 89%; yellow viscous liquid. 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ =1.6 (s, 4H), δ =2.3–2.9 (bm, 24H), δ =3.3–3.7 (bm, 12H), δ =3.7–3.9 (sextet, 2H); 13C NMR: 26.4, 53.3, 58.0, 60.8, 66.2, 71.5, 73.4; MS (ESI) m/e: calcd for C22H46N4O6 (M+): 462.34, found (M+H)+: 463.34; elemental analysis: calcd (%) for C22H46N4O6: C 57.12, H 10.02, N 12.11, O 20.75; found: C 57.92, H 10.10, N 11.94, O 20.04). 2.5.6 Catalyst 6 (tetrakis(N,N-diethylethanol)propanediamine) 1,3-Diaminopropane (8.0g) was added to a 250-mL round-bottomed flask. N,N-Diethyl glycidyl amine (51.68g) was added to the flask dropwise over a period of 5min. The mixture was heated at 80°C for 20h under nitrogen. NMR analysis demonstrated the absence of epoxide. Volatiles were removed by rotary evaporation, and the excess N,N-diethyl glycidyl amine was removed using a high vacuum at 100°C for 1day to yield Catalyst 6 (52.5g; yield: 88%; yellow liquid. 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3, 25°C, TMS) δ =0.98 (t, 24H), δ =1.6 (quintet, 2H), δ =2.2–2.7 (bm, 36H), δ =3.7 (bm, 4H); 13C NMR: 11.9, 24.3, 47.2, 53.4, 57.7, 59.8, 66.0; MS (ESI) m/e: calcd for C31H70N6O4 (M+): 590.55, found (M+H)+: 591.55; elemental analysis: calcd (%) for C31H70N6O4: C 63.00, H 11.94, N 14.22, O 10.83; found: C 62.69, H 12.13, N 14.30, O 10.97). 2.5.7 Catalyst 7 (tris(N,N-diethylethanol)aminoethylpiperazine) 1-(2-Aminoethyl)piperazine (14.0g) was added to a 250-mL round-bottomed flask. N,N-Diethyl glycidyl amine (38.76g) was added to the flask dropwise over a period of 5min. The mixture was heated at 80°C for 20h under nitrogen. NMR analysis demonstrated the absence of epoxide. Volatiles were removed by rotary evaporation, and the excess N,N-diethyl glycidyl amine was removed using a high vacuum at 100°C for 1day to yield Catalyst 7 (46.4g; yield: 88%; yellow liquid. 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3, 25°C, TMS) δ =0.9 (t, 18H), δ =2.2–2.82 (bm, 35H), δ =3.59–3.9 (bm, 4H); 13C NMR: 9.7, 45.2, 51.5, 53.8, 55.6, 57.8, 58.3, 60.4, 62.3, 64.1, 64.6; MS (ESI) m/e: calcd for C27H60N6O4 (M+): 516.47, found (M+H)+: 517.48; elemental analysis: calcd (%) for C27H60N6O4: C 61.75, H 11.70, N 16.76, O:9.79; found: C 61.81, H 11.68, N 16.91, O 9.58). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Cycloaddition reaction using various multifunctional alkanolamine catalysts Our motivation to design and synthesize the new catalyst is to develop metal- and halide-free catalysts that are better for CO2 conversion than conventional CO2-adsorbent or natural materials [48,59,60]. We considered diversifying the number of active sites (hydroxyl groups and tertiary amine groups) and the structure of the organic catalysts. Therefore, seven catalysts with different structures, as shown in Fig. 1 , were synthesized by reacting epoxy chemicals with secondary and primary amines. There were two, three, and four hydroxyl groups and two, four, and six amine groups; each contained methylamines or ethylamines and a monoalkanolamine commercial amine scrubber (dimethylpropanolamine, Catalyst 8), as shown in Table 1 . The catalytic synthesis of cyclic carbonates from PO and CO2 using 1.0mol% multifunctional alkanolamine was performed in a stainless steel autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer at 10bar and 120°C for 3h. The selectivity and yield of PC were determined by gas chromatography. The results are provided in Table 1. Among the multifunctional catalysts, Catalyst 6 and Catalyst 7 did not achieve more than a 40% yield of PC, while Catalyst 2, Catalyst 4, and Catalyst 5 provided more than a 76% yield. Specifically, Catalyst 2 and Catalyst 4 demonstrated good PC yields of 83% and 86%, respectively, with PC selectivities of more than 99%. Catalyst 3 showed a low activity (18%) and still afforded a low activity (40%), even though the loading was increased by as much as a factor of three. Its low activity likely resulted from its low functionality (two N atoms and two hydroxyl groups), and it did not show any significant synergy effects. The best performance was provided by Catalyst 1, which attained a 96% PC yield in the cycloaddition of CO2 and PO with 99% selectivity. The PC yields could have resulted from the different catalyst structures. One of the main controlling factors was the bulkiness of the substituent on the amine [44]. The methylamine group (in Catalyst 1, Catalyst 2, and Catalyst 4) gave a better PC yield than the ethylamine group (in Catalyst 6 and Catalyst 7). This could be caused by the presence of more basic piperazine groups (cyclic amines tend to be more basic than acyclic ones), which could also explain the higher reactivities of Catalysts 1, 2, and 4. Bulky structures would block the lone pair electrons on the N atom, which played an important role in attacking the electrophilic center carbon of CO2, reducing the PC yield [42]. The other factor influencing the PC yield was the number of amine and hydroxyl groups in the multifunctional catalysts. This suggested that a larger number of amine and hydroxyl groups in the catalysts produced more PC. A monoalkanolamine commercial amine scrubber (dimethylpropanolamine, Catalyst 8) did not provide a good activity, and the synergistic effects of the catalyst were not observed. Catalyst 8 (1.0mol%) provided a carbonate yield of 31%; the yield was not even doubled (yield=57%) using 4.0mol% (i.e., a four times higher amount) of Catalyst 8 (Table 1). Therefore, simply increasing the amount of catalyst does not increase the activity. When there are many functional groups in the same molecule, they show synergistic effects and their activities can increase. Synergistic effects have been reported for OH groups and halogens, as described in the introduction of this work. However, we observed that several amine groups synergize with each other and multiple OH groups synergize with each other in addition to the synergistic effects between amine groups and OH groups. To further test the structural properties, Catalyst 1–1, Catalyst 2–1, and Catalyst 4–1 (which are shown in Fig. 2 and have the same structures as Catalyst 1, Catalyst 2, and Catalyst 4, respectively) were synthesized by reacting with methyl pyperidine instead of methyl pyperazine to place carbon at the end of the molecule instead of nitrogen. The role of N in the same structure could be compared through the CO2 conversion reaction. The experimental results are summarized in Table 2 , and the yields of the catalysts without N at the end of the structure were 20–30% less than that of the previous experiment. Thus, amine groups in the same structure can affect the reaction through a synergistic effect, as would be expected from the role of nitrogen (as discussed above). 3.2 Proposed mechanism of Catalyst 1 CO2 activation can occur using two different types of organocatalysts [61,62]. However, the activation mechanism for our catalysts is slightly different from that found in these studies. The mechanism of the multifunctional alkanolamine in our synthesized catalysts is similar with the literature [48]. According to our experiments, a synergistic effect could arise from the structural arrangement of functional groups in the multifunctional amine catalyst; these functional groups could be an important factor for providing a high PC yield. Therefore, DFT calculations were performed to estimate the stable molecular conformation of the multifunctional amine catalysts (Fig. 3 ). The three hydrogens at the center of Catalyst 1 were closely gathered: H(center)-H(left) distance of 2.216Å, H(center)-H(right) distance of 2.193Å, and H(left)-H(right) distance of 3.708Å (Fig. 3(a)). Two facing methylpiperazines (with lone pairs on the nitrogen atoms) approached each other and were positioned to supply more adsorbed gaseous CO2 than the other multifunctional amine catalysts. Therefore, we propose that three hydroxyl groups could strongly adsorb epoxide, and a ring-opening reaction occurs more efficiently by accepting more CO2 from both sides of the amine groups. The molecular conformations of Catalyst 2 and Catalyst 4 are shown in Fig. 3(b) and (c), respectively. The hydroxyl groups in the two catalysts are too far from each other (Catalyst 2: 11.870Å, Catalyst 4: 7.305Å, 8.390Å, and 9.672Å) to provide a synergy effect. The catalytic mechanism of alkanolamine containing one amine and one hydroxyl group has been previously described using Catalyst 8 [48]. However, no explanations exist for multifunctional alkanolamine catalysis for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxide by a synergy effect. In the presence of CO2 and PO with Catalyst 1, the form of the catalyst is shown in the Fig. S1, and the values of ΔE were calculated as 2.0, 2.3, and 11.1kcal/mol for Catalyst 1, Catalyst 2, and Catalyst 4, respectively. As a result, the most stable structure was obtained when CO2 and PO approached Catalyst 1, and this can explain the increased yield. The proposed CO2 cycloaddition mechanism of Catalyst 1 is shown in Scheme 3 . The three close hydroxyl groups of Catalyst 1 formed a stronger hydrogen bond with the oxygen of PO than that of the catalyst with one hydroxyl group. The lone-pair electrons on the four nitrogen atoms in Catalyst 1 interact with electrophilic carbon atoms of CO2. Therefore, it becomes easier for the epoxide to participate in ring-opening reactions and activates the nucleophilic attack of the oxygen atom of CO2 on the carbocationic center of the PO molecule. Four amines in two facing methylpiperazines exhibited synergistic effects because the catalyst molecules were curved forms (refer to Scheme 3), as predicted by DFT. Reactants, such as CO2 and PO surrounded by functional groups in curved Catalyst 1, could exhibit better catalytic performances than the other multifunctional and commercial alkanol amines. In the next step, a hydrogen atom from a hydroxyl group was transferred to the epoxide oxygen, which remained as an oxy anion, resulting in nucleophilic attack occurring at the carbon atom of CO2 and forming the resulting carbonate linkage. Then, the proton of the ring-opened epoxide reverted to its destination to regenerate the amino alcohol catalyst, while cycloaddition furnished the cyclic carbonate [48]. 3.3 The reaction of Catalyst 1 under various conditions The best catalyst, Catalyst 1, was further tested at various reaction times, as shown in Table 3 (a). The reaction of PO and CO2 using Catalyst 1 (1.4mol%) attained a 98.0% yield in 3h at 120°C and an initial CO2 pressure of 10bar. When using a small amount of the catalyst (0.14mol%), PC was produced in a 40.6% yield in 3h. After continuously reacting for 24h, the PC yield finally exceeded 98%. This shows that the catalyst is stable for 24h at 120°C and 10bar. A reaction performed at high temperature (140°C) using one fifth of the amount of catalyst used in the previous reaction (0.28mol%) afforded a PC yield of 99% without other byproducts. Experiments were performed under the same conditions by varying the amount of Catalyst 1, which is summarized in Table 3(b). When the amount of the catalyst was 0.14mol%, the yield was only 40%. When the catalyst amount was increased to 1.4mol%, the PC yield reached 98%. In addition, when the catalyst amount was increased to 5.6mol%, a yield of 90% was obtained, even under mild condition 7 (5bar, 100°C). 3.4 Experimental design for RSM (response surface methodology) From the above reaction results, a more systematic analysis of the reaction variables, such as catalyst amount, reaction temperature, and CO2 pressure, was required to closely examine the new organic catalyst. Therefore, a BBD was employed in this study to optimize the reaction conditions and investigate the effect of the variables on the PC yield. BBD was one of the most important and uncomplicated designs among several RSM designs. This design required fewer experiments than other designs, making it economical [63,64]. In this reaction, one response (Y) was the yield of propylene carbonate (%), and the three independent variables, X1, X2, and X3, were the amount of catalyst (mol%), initial CO2 pressure (bar), and temperature (°C), respectively, as shown in Table S2. Fifteen experiments, including twelve factorial points and three replicates at the center point for the estimation of the pure error sum of the squares, were performed based on the BBD matrix generated by the Design-Expert software [57]. The responses of the fifteen experiments are listed in Table 4 . The model was able to generate response surfaces and contour curves for the analysis of the variable effects on the PC yield. The response surface and contour curves for PC yield (%) were obtained using Eq. (1): (1) Y=90.14+12.45X1 +15.59X2 +13.11X3 −13.50X1X3 +14.88X2X3 −20.37X2 2 −8.45X3 2 Interactions between coded variables (−1, 0, 1) and responses are shown using three-dimensional surface plots [65,66]. Response surfaces and contour plots are commonly used to evaluate relationships among parameters and predict results under given conditions [67]. Eq. (1) can be interpreted as all linear factors with a positive effect on the PC yield and square of the initial CO2 pressure related to the PC yield. The catalytic amounts and initial CO2 pressure have no interactions with each other; the catalyst content and temperature as well as the CO2 pressure and temperature interact with each other to influence the PC yield. The BBD (according to Eq. (1)) provided the optimum values for the reaction temperature and pressure with respect to the amount of Catalyst 1, as shown in Fig. 4 . The PC yield was 95% when the temperature and pressure were within the inner ellipse shown in red (Fig. 4(c)). The optimum conditions (95% yield) were about 9.6bar and 120°C with 0.84mol% of the catalyst. When the catalyst was reduced to 0.28 mol% (Fig. 4(a)), 95% PO was converted to PC under harsher conditions (142°C and 12.0bar). Fig. 4(b) shows that the optimum conditions were about 11.0bar and 137°C using 0.56mol% of the catalyst. At 120°C, the initial CO2 pressure had little effect on the PC yield because the CO2 pressure variation did not accelerate the reaction under these conditions. When the temperature reached 130°C, the increasing initial CO2 pressure provided a high PC yield with a constant amount of catalyst. At a low initial CO2 pressure (∼5bar), the PC yield changed broadly with increasing temperature from 120 to 150°C. The temperature change provided only a small effect on the PC yield, which could have been due to the difficult cycloaddition reaction at a low CO2 pressure. With a further increase of the initial CO2 pressure (>10bar), the increased reaction temperature induced a high PC yield. 4 Conclusions In summary, seven new multifunctional alkanol amine catalysts were synthesized and used for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. Catalyst 1 (1.4mol%) provided the best yield (98.0%) at 10bar and 120°C. Under mild conditions, such as 5bar and 100°C, a 90% yield of PO could be obtained using 5.6mol% catalyst in 8h. The number of active sites, such as hydroxyl groups and tertiary amine groups in alkanol amine, affected the catalyst performance. The performance was also affected by the structure of the catalysts, which could provide synergistic effects (1) between the hydroxyl and amine groups, (2) between the hydroxyl groups, and (3) between the amine groups in one organic catalyst molecule. DFT calculations of the stable conformational state of Catalyst 1 could assume that the CO2 and PO cycloaddition reaction effectively occurred at the inner site of the catalyst. The proposed reaction mechanism shows the activation of CO2 through the nucleophilic attack of the oxygen atom of CO2 on the carbocationic center of the PO molecule. From this mechanism and our experiments, we may be able to explain why Catalyst 1 provided a better performance. In addition, the optimum reaction conditions (pressure and temperature) at three catalytic amounts were calculated using the BBD. coredata.dc:description: Multifunctional alkanolamines without metals or halides were designed as catalysts for the synthesis of propylene carbonate (PC) by the cycloaddition of CO2 and propylene oxide (PO). New catalysts were synthesized in a one-step, low-temperature reaction. Among the multifunctional alkanolamine catalysts, bis(methylpiperazinyl)triol (Catalyst 1) showed the best performance, with a 96% yield of PO in 3h at 120°C and 10bar using 1mol% catalyst. A 90% yield of PO could be obtained using 5.60mol% of Catalyst 1 under mild conditions (100°C and 5bar). A reaction mechanism was proposed based on the synergistic effects between the hydroxyl and amine groups in one multifunctional molecule. The effects of the reaction parameters (temperature, CO2 pressure, and catalyst loading) on the yield of PC were interpreted using response surface methodology. The metal- and halide-free catalysts will facilitate an environmentally friendly process for the application of other carbonates.
coredata.dc:title: Multifunctional alkanolamine as a catalyst for CO2 and propylene oxide cycloaddition
